title: Jerry Coyne Once Again
post: Ancient contemporary historical documents in accessible archives are usually confined to ruling houses, conquering generals, and accounts of wars, seldom to notable religious reformers unless they formed part of the establishment.  I wonder what contemporary historical documentation there might be for the existence of Lao Tzu, Siddartha Gautama (founder of Indian Buddhism), Confucius, or for that matter Moses. Yet as with Jesus, their movements survive them.

title: Jerry Coyne Once Again

Ancient contemporary historical documents in accessible archives are usually confined to ruling houses, conquering generals, and accounts of wars, seldom to notable religious reformers unless they formed part of the establishment. I wonder what contemporary historical documentation there might be for the existence of Lao Tzu, Siddartha Gautama (founder of Indian Buddhism), Confucius, or for that matter Moses. Yet as with Jesus, their movements survive them.
Last year, I had read an interesting book on those matters. The title was Walter Vogel Ojcowie religii (original German title was Die Religionsstifter, ‘The founders of religion’). It had biographies of following religious figures: Moses, Buddha, Muhhammad, Akhenaten, Zoroaster, Confucius, Laozi, Mani, Guru Nanak and Bahá’u’lláh. Except for the two last figures from the relatively modern period, it seems that the life of Jesus is the best documented.
